an11.12:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
an11.12:4.2: Now at that time Mahānāma the Sakyan had recently recovered from an illness.
an11.12:4.3: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha …
an11.12:5.1: Mahānāma the Sakyan heard about this.
an11.12:5.4: He went up to the Buddha,
an11.12:5.5: bowed, sat down to one side,
an11.12:5.8: several mendicants are making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
an11.12:5.9: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
an11.12:5.10: Now, we spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?”
an11.12:6.2: It’s appropriate that respectable people such as you come to me and ask:
an11.12:6.3: ‘We spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?’
an11.12:6.4: The faithful succeed, not the faithless.
an11.12:6.5: The energetic succeed, not the lazy.
an11.12:6.6: The mindful succeed, not the unmindful.
an11.12:6.7: Those with samādhi succeed, not those without samādhi.
an11.12:6.8: The wise succeed, not the witless.
an11.12:6.9: When you’re grounded on these five things, go on to develop six further things.
an11.12:7.1: Firstly, you should recollect the Realized One:
an11.12:7.2: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people,
an11.12:7.3: teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
an11.12:7.4: When a noble disciple recollects the Realized One their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion.
an11.12:7.5: At that time their mind is unswerving, based on the Realized One.
an11.12:7.6: A noble disciple whose mind is unswerving finds joy in the meaning and the teaching, and finds gladness connected with the teaching.
an11.12:7.7: When you’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, you feel bliss. And when you’re blissful, the mind comes together in samādhi.
an11.12:7.8: You should develop this recollection of the Buddha while walking, standing, sitting, lying down, while engaged in work, and while at home with your children.
an11.12:8.1: Furthermore, you should recollect the teaching …
an11.12:8.13: When a noble disciple recollects the faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom of both themselves and the gods their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion.
an11.12:8.14: At that time their mind is unswerving, based on the gods.
an11.12:8.15: A noble disciple whose mind is unswerving finds joy in the meaning and the teaching, and finds gladness connected with the teaching.
an11.12:8.16: When you’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, you feel bliss. And when you’re blissful, the mind comes together in samādhi.
an11.12:8.17: You should develop this recollection of the gods while walking, standing, sitting, lying down, while engaged in work, and while at home with your children.”
